etymologies: late Middle English ele, ile, from Old French ele, from Latin ala ‘wing’. The spelling change in the 17th century was due to confusion with isle and influenced by French aile ‘wing’

definitions: a passage between rows of seats in a building such as a church or theater, an airplane, or a train

examples.text: the musical had the audience dancing in the aisles

shortDefinitions: passage between rows of seats in building

definitions: a passage between shelves of goods in a supermarket or other building

examples.text: I spend much of my time at the shops, wandering through the aisles

shortDefinitions: passage between cabinets and shelves of goods in supermarket

definitions: (in a church) a lower part parallel to and at the side of a nave, choir, or transept, from which it is divided by pillars

examples.text: the tiled roof over the south aisle

shortDefinitions: (in church) lower part parallel to nave, choir, or transept
